content: Yes, it's the best way. On Win, the folder you're copying/pasting is C:\Users\<useername>\AppData\Roaming\Thunderbird, and I recommend deleting that folder on the target drive before pasting (vs. overwriting it).

content:
Uninstall reinstall is a complete waste of time in this instance as it will not fix the server issuing an invalid certificate. Perhaps you could advise that that server name is. The images are so microscopic that I can not read them. With the server name I could check the certificate that they send when contacted to look for a clue as to why it is invalid.

You need to determine why you are being offered an invalid certificate by the server.

If it is a hosted domain it may be the certificated is not valid because it has the hosts name on it, not your domain. If you have an antivirus scanning incoming mail, it could be that the antivirus is issuing a self signed certificate that is not valid without you undertaking a manual addition of the antivirus vendor as a trusted certifying authority for encryption.

I suggest you have a look in the error console(ctrl+shift+J) and see what messages appear there at the same time as that dialog appears. That might shed some additional light as to what the real problem is.
creator: MattAuSupport

content:
Maybe you could use the following add-on so that the folders are not moved accidentally: Disable DragAndDrop (New) https://addons.thunderbird.net/en-US/thunderbird/addon/disable-draganddrop-tb-v2/

Quotation from the above link:

Disable drag and drop on the folder tree in order to prevent unintended folder movement.

content:
Per poter inquadrare il problema prova a fornire queste informazioni:

  1. Versione di Thunderbird
  2. Versione del sistema operativo
  3. Provider delle caselle email (Gmail, Libero, Hotmail, etc.)
  4. Tipologia di account (POP3, IMAP)
  5. Estensioni installate
  6. Messaggi di errore che vengono visualizzati durante l'utilizzo di Thunderbird
  7. Software di sicurezza eventualmente presenti (Antivirus e simili)
  8. Screenshot del problema (se utile a chiarire il contesto)

content: Thunderbird (come Firefox) è un software gratuito offerto a tutti senza garanzie. Ovviamente quindi non offre supporto tecnico. Questo è solo un forum per gli utenti. Se pensi di aver bisogno di supporto diretto ti conviene contattare qualcuno che si occupi di assistenza informatica nella tua zona.
creator: @next

content: This is more an HTML question. The border attribute in the advanced editor sets the width of the border. To set the color, you need to manually add HTML tag for that, and to do that you need to have an HTML editor addon such as this one: https://betterbird.eu/addons/

content:
Okay, easy enough. Attached screens for incoming and smtp. No error messages on *my* machine (other than the one I described, which isn't even an error message, just status), but my wife's machine (which is having the same exact issue) gets this message upon startup (can't provide a screenshot of that one, sorry.): "Mozilla Thunderbird esr Thunderbird The certification for mail.myfairpoint.net is not valid for that server. Someone could be trying to impersonate the server and you should not continue."

And that's it - - no "proceed anyway" option, only options that come up with the ellipsis have to do with whether or not windows displays notifications for this app... so not really relevant. I can turn the message off, but Tbird still won't work, and I'm at a loss to explain why she gets that message and I don't. Same email provider, same settings, only difference being her actual email address (differs by one character.)

I've already contacted my provider twice - - they're utterly useless. All support has been farmed out to script-readers in some other country, who can't fix it and promise a callback. They don't support Thunderbird, just MS Outlook and the main Apple app, whatever that is. Been waiting for two weeks for that callback. Only reason I'm here is that other apps manage to connect okay (receive and send), and Tbird won't.

content: We cannot know what your phone's settings are, but they need to be IMAP if you want to be in sync with IMAP on PC.. Your other question was answered in a separate thread.
creator: davidsk

content: First, you cannot change an existing account setup; you must create a separate IMAP account. No, you will not lose any messages. However, all previously downloaded messages that were removed from the server need to be copied to Local Folders; otherwise, you will lose those messages when you close the account.
